chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Columba is an email-client written in Java, featuring a user-friendly graphical interface with time-saving wizards and internationalization support.
This guide will help you to get started quickly with Columba.

section.title: Typographical conventions
section.para: In this book, we'll mark some words with special typography:
Commands you type at the command line
Labels for buttons and other portions of the graphical interface
Menu selections look like this: Menu->Submenu->Menu Item
We'll provide assorted bits of additional information in tips set off from the rest of the book, as well.

tip.para: Tips and bits of extra information will look like this.

section.title: Additional Help Sources
section.para: You will find the most up-to-date information on our website at http://columba.sf.net in the Documentation section.

section.title: License
section.para: Columba is free software that is licensed under the Mozilla Public License. This license allows you to use, modify and redistribute this software. There's a nice FAQ which should answer most of your questions. Note, that we have choosen this license intentially to become more business-friendly. There's no virual effect as seen with the GPL here.

Columba is not a monolithic application. It makes use of dynamically loaded extensions. These extensions are what we call plugins. The MPL License lets you create closed-source or binary plugins and allows you to sell these without a problem.

chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: Download Columba from http://columba.sf.net and be sure to read the information provided on our Download page.

sect1.title: Prerequisites
sect1.para: Columba is written entirely in Java and therefore is platform independent. It runs on almost any modern personal computer. To successfully start and run Columba you need the following:

Java Runtime Environment or Java Development Kit. JDK 1.4 or higher is required for Linux, Mac OS X, and Windows Platforms. Columba will not run with JDK 1.3 or older. We recommend to use Java 5 for superior performance.
A computer with reasonable memory and CPU power. For memory, 512 MB is recommended. For CPU, a Pentium III or equivalent is the recommended minimum.

A specific operating system is not required. Columba is known to run on Windows 98, 2000, NT, and XP, on Linux, and MacOS X. It has been predominantly developed and tested on Linux (mostly Gentoo Linux and/or Ubuntu Linux).

sect1.title: Windows
sect1.para: The preferred way should be to download ColumbaSetup.exe. Double-click the file to start the setup. A wizard will guide you step-by-step throughout the installation process.

sect1.title: Linux
sect1.para: Download the RPM (the RPM Package Manager) package of Columba. You have to become root user in order to be able to install Columba. Enter
in your favourite shell. This will install Columba in /opt/columba and will create a symbolic link in /usr/bin/columba.
The RPM package does not have any dependency checking built-in. It therefor won't check if you installed a matching Java RPM.

sect1.title: Generic
sect1.para: Download the binary package and extract its contents.

chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: This chapter introduces all basic concepts of Columba. It will help you setup an email account, checking for new mail, composing and sending a message.
Here is a list of things that you should look up before you start Columba for the first time:

listitem.para: Your POP3 or IMAP server for incoming email, which usually is named similar to "pop3.yahoo.com"
Your SMTP server for outgoing email, which usually is named similar to "smtp.yahoo.com"
Your username and password for your POP3- or IMAP-account

chapter.para: You should contact your ISP (Internet Service Provider) or your system administrator if you do not know these settings.

section.title: Starting Columba for the First Time
section.para: To start Columba do one of the following:

listitem.para: Select Programs->Columba from your menu panel
Type columba at the command line

section.para: The first time you run the program it will create a directory .columba in your home directory. Windows users can find this directory in C:\Documents and Settings\USER\.columba. Just replace USER with your username.
It will then open up a first-time wizard which will guide you in creating a mail account.

section.title: Command Line Options
section.para: Columba has a number of command line options which come in handy you. You can find the full list by running columba -help.

listitem.para: To start Columba and begin composing a message to a email address: columba --mailurl peter@somewhere.com

To make your web browser use Columba as default email client, enter columba --mailurl %s as the email handler in your web browser. When using the windows installer you do not have to do this manually. Columba will automatically ask you if you want it to make it the system default email client.

section.title: Setting Up Your Account
section.para:
Setting up your account involves several steps:
Entering your identity including name and email address
Configuring your incoming mail server
Specifying your outgoing mail server
This is the real name assigned to this identity - generally your first and a last name. The text you enter here is included in the From: field of all your outgoing messages.
Specify your email address here.
Choose a name for this new account. When using multiple accounts this will help you distinguishing them from each other.

This is the name you use to log on to this email account. For example, in the upcoming mail account donald@mail.com, the login name is donald. This is a very common scheme used by most providers. Check with your Internet Service Provider if you are not sure what your login name is.
Name of your incoming mail server.
This indicates the email protocol this incoming email server uses: POP3 or IMAP. If you are not sure which to use, ask your administrator. In most cases it is POP3.
Name of your outgoing mail server.
You are now ready to work with Columba!

section.title: Receiving Messages
section.para: To check your email, press the Receive/Send toolbar button or the F9 Function Key. If this is the first time you are checking mail, or you have not asked Columba to save your password, you will be prompted for the password. Enter your password and your email will be downloaded.

section.title: Sending Messages
section.para: Click the New Message item in the menu Message to open the composer window. Alternatively you can use the New Message button in the toolbar.
While online, after composing your message press the Send Now button or alternatively select File->Send Message. If you are not online, select File->Send Later

chapter.title: Using Columba
chapter.para: New messages can be found in the Inbox folder. The Inbox label will be bold when the mailbox contains recent messages. The number in the brackets reflects the total number of unread messages. When moving the mouse cursor above the mailbox a tooltip with additional information appears.

New messages in the message list view are marked in bold. A little envelope symbol in the first column shows if the message has already been read (has "open" envelope) or not (has "closed" envelope). When selecting a message in the message list, it will automatically be shown in the message view. If the message has an attachment, it will have a little paperclip icon in the second column.

The message view shows the header of all messages, with the most important information listed first: Subject, Sender, Date and From.The message body text follows with the message signature underneath. If the message contains attachments a paperclip symbol in the message header notifies the user.
The attachment viewer lets you select attachments to individually open, view or save to files with the context menu.

section.title: Reading Mail
section.para: Start reading messages by selecting a mail folder in the tree view. To read a message select it in the message list; if you would like to see it in its own window, double-click it.

section.title: Reading Mail with the Keyboard
section.para: You can navigate the message list by pressing the arrow keys up and down. To jump to the next unread message press n. You can go to the previous unread message by pressing p.

section.title: Sorting the Message List
section.para:
Columba helps your organise your messages by letting you sort your email. To sort by sender, subject or date, click on the buttons with those labels on top of the message list. The direction of the arrow next to the label indicates the direction of the sort, and if you click again, you will sort them in the reverse order.
To look at the complete headers for email messages, select View->Message Display->Show Full Headers. To see absolutely every bit, choose View->Show Message Source.

You can also choose a threaded message view. Select View->Threaded View to turn the threaded view on and off. When you select this option, Columba groups the replies to a message with the original so you can follow the thread of conversation.

section.title: Filtering the Message List
section.para: To show new messages only:

listitem.para: Select the left-most read message button

section.para: To show only new messages from donald@duck.com:

listitem.para: Enter "donald@duck.com" in the textfield and press Enter

section.para:
All filter operations can be easily combined in this way. To view all messages again, press the Clear button.
Pressing the Advanced.. button will open a search dialog, with the currently viewed folder already selected for you.

section.title: Deleting your Mail
section.para: Once you have read your mail, you may want to get rid of it. To delete a message:

listitem.para: Select the message(s), you want to delete
Select Messages->Delete Messages, or right click on the message and select Delete Messages or hit the Delete key.
Hold down the Shift key to select a range of messages you want to delete
Hold down the Ctrl key to select multiple messages individually

tip.para: Use the Delete button in the toolbar!

section.para: This does not delete your messages immediately. Instead it moves messages to the Trash folder.

section.title: Saving or Opening attachments
section.para: If you get an attachment with your email message, Columba can help you save or open it with the appropriate application.
To save an attachment to disk:

listitem.para: Right-click the attachment icon and select Save As..
Choose a location and a name for the file
click OK

section.para: To open an attachment in a program:

listitem.para: Open the mail message with the attachment you want to read
Right-click the attachment icon and Select Open With...
Select the program you would like to use. It will start up and open the document.

tip.para: Double-clicking the attachment icon will open the attachment with the previously chosen program.

section.title: Checking for New Mail
section.para: Use the Get New Messages or the Get New Messages for... items in the File menu to individually download new messages from one account or from all accounts at once. To automatically send and receive all messages press the Receive and Send button in the toolbar.

section.title: Composing New Email Messages
section.para: Click Message->New Message or hit Ctrl-M to open the composer window. Alternatively you can use the New Message button in the toolbar.

section.title: Composing a Message

listitem.para: Enter the person you want to send a message to in the upper left corner textfield. Press the TAB button to automatically jump to the Subject textfield.

Enter the subject you want. This is the first line the person will read, so it should be pretty clear and descriptive in order to allow the person to categorize the message. Remember also that a lot of people use the subject field to decide on what messages might be spam. Sending a message with a subject "Hello!" to someone who might not recognise your email address is a sure way to get your message deleted without even being read. Pressing TAB again will show the prompt in the message body textfield.
This is where you write your message. Note: You can quickly choose your preferred account and the message priority by using controls in the middle of the composer dialog.

section.para: Once you have written your message, click the Send Now button or select File->Send Now or press Ctrl-Enter if you are online or select File->Send Later if you are offline.

section.title: Sending Composed Messages Later
section.para: Columba will normally send mail as soon as you click the Send Later button. However, there are a few ways you can save a message to be sent later:

listitem.para: If you are offline, Columba will add your messages to the Outbox queue. The next time you are online and send or receive mail, that message will be sent when you select File->Send Unsent Messages or click the F10 function key. It will not be sent as part of a normal File->Receive and Send selection or by pressing the F9 function key.
Choose File->Save As Draft to store your messages in the draft folder

section.title: Adding Attachments
section.para: To attach a file to your message:

listitem.para: Press the Attach File button on the composer toolbar or select Message->Attach File or press Ctrl-Alt-A key combination.
Select the file you want to attach using the dialog box that is displayed.
Press OK

tip.para: You can add multiple attachments at once.

When you send the message, a copy of the attachment will go with it. Be aware that it may take a while depending on the current speed of your internet connection to send large attachments. Remember also that the attachment(s) will be sent to all recipients so if you do not want some to receive it, you will have to do transactions.

section.title: Specifying Recipients for Email
section.para: Like most email programs, Columba recognizes three types of addresses: Primary recipients, secondary recipients and hidden ("blind") recipients.
The simplest way to direct a message is to put the address in the To: field, which denotes primary recipients. To send a message to more than one or two people, use the Cc: field.
"Cc" stands for "Carbon Copy" (if you need further explanation, ask someone familiar with typewriters!). Use it whenever you want to share a message you have written with someone else.

Bcc: (Blind Carbon Copy) is a little bit more complex. You use it like Cc:, but people on the Bcc: list are hidden from the other recipients of the message. Use it to send a mail to a large group of people, especially if they don't know each other, privacy is a concern or you are sharing a secrets.

tip.para: In these days where Spam is more prevalent than real Email, it is a very good idea to use Bcc instead of Cc whenever possible. There are an increasing number of viruses and other internet nasties that are very capable of scanning all of your stored messages for new addresses and then forwarding these addresses on for sending further spam.

Now you might be very internet savy and have defenses against such problems but do all the people you correspond with? It only takes one message on an insecure machine and you have inadvertantly become part of the problem.

When using Bcc, the recipient of the message only sees your email address and his own because the email server creates a new message for each email address in your Bcc list. Email is for commmunication, not to show how many people you know!

section.para: If you frequently write mail to the same group of people, you can create address lists in the addressbook, and then send them mail as though they had a single address.

section.title: Address Auto-completion
section.para:
Columba automatically saves address in its Collect Addresses book. When entering addresses it will offer a drop down list of possible address completions from your addressbooks and the Collected Addresses.
You can also enter nicknames, here.

Alternatively you can click on the contact button (the one that looks like a small photo ID) in the composer toolbar to open a dialog, to get you a list of the email addresses in your addressbook. Select addresses and click the arrows to move the addresses into the appropriate address columns.
You can use drag and drop in the dialog, to create the recipients list.

section.title: Replying to Email Messages
section.para: To reply to an email press the Reply button, or select Message->Reply to Message alternatively. That will open the message composer. The To: and Subject: fields are already filled, although you can change them if you wish. In addition the full text of the old message is inserted into the new message, with a ">" character in front of each line. This should indicate that its part of the previous message.
If you are reading a message with several recipients you might want to use Message->Reply to All instead.

tip.para: Message->Reply to Mailinglist tries to determine the list name for you. This is the preferred way of replying when participating in mailing lists.

section.title: Forwarding Mail
section.para: Forwarding mail is particularly useful if you have received a message and you think someone else would like to see it. You can forward a message as an attachment by selecting Message->Forward as Attachment, or you can send it inline as a quoted portion of the message you are sending.

section.title: Using Multiple Accounts
section.para: Every account shares the same Inbox mailfolder for receiving messages. You can change the default behaviour in the account preferences dialog under the Special Folders Tab. This enables you to use different mailfolders for each account and makes using multiple accounts more convenient.

When using File->Get New Messages for, you can choose which account you want to check. Selecting File->Get New Messages item (or by pressing Ctrl-T) makes it easy to check for new messages in all accounts simultaneously.

The composer lets you choose the outgoing mailserver. When replying to messages, Columba automatically tries to guess the correct account for you. You can choose one account to be your default account. This is the account Columba chooses when it cannot determine the correct account and it is also the default account when opening a new composer window.

section.title: Importing Your Old Email
section.para: Columba allows you to import old email and data, so that you do not have to worry about losing your old information.
Columba can import the following types of data:

listitem.para: Mbox (mbox) - The email format used by most email clients. One single file containing a complete mail folder
MH style mailbox (mh) - A folder containing a single file for every message
Mozilla (mbox)
Evolution (mbox)
Pegasus Mail (mbox)

tip.para: Visit our website at to get the most up-to-date information about importing data in Columba.

section.para: To import your old email:

listitem.para: Click Utilities->Import Mailbox...
Choose the email format, click Next
Choose the file and the destination folder in Columba, click Next
Click Finish

section.title: Getting Organized with Folders
section.para: Columba keeps mail in folders. You start out with a few mail folders, such as Inbox, Outbox, Drafts, Templates, Sent and Trash, but you can create as many as you like.
Create new folders by selecting Folder->Create new Subfolder... Columba will ask you for the name and type of your new folder, and will provide you with a folder tree so you can pick where it goes.

When you click OK, your new folder will appear in the folder view. You can cut/copy/paste messages between your folders. Alternatively you can use the Move Messages button or Copy Messages button in the toolbar.
Toolbar

tip.para: You can also use drag and drop to copy/move messages between folders.

section.title: Create Filter Rules to Automatically Organize Mail
section.para: It is important to note that filters are attached to folders and only act on a specific folder. Firstly, select the folder you wish to attach a filter to (most commonly Inbox). You then open the filter dialog by clicking Folder->Message Filters.. This enables you to manage all filters of this folder. You can easily (de)activate filters individually by selecting the checkbox in the column Enabled.
This creates a new filter and automatically opens a new Filter Options Dialog to let you edit the filter properties.
This opens the Filter Options Dialog to edit your filter properties.
Deletes the selected filter.

tip.para: When opening multiple Filter Dialogs you can drag and drop filters between folders.Filters are executed in the order specified by this dialog.
Use the Up and Down buttons to change the order.

section.para: This dialog lets you change filter properties. You can open it when selecting a filter and pressing the Edit button. The upper panel lets you add/edit/remove filter criteria. The lower panel enables you to edit filter actions:
Specify a descriptive name for your filter.
If you have more than one filter criteria you can choose in this checkbox if all or only one criteria needs to match to start the filter action.

listitem.para: Subject - The subject line of the message.
From - From headerfield should contain/not contain specified string.
To - To headerfield should contain/not contain specified string.
Cc - Cc headerfield should contain/not contain specified string.
Bcc - Bcc headerfield should contain/not contain specified string.
Custom Headerfield - The filter can look at any header you want, even custom ones. Enter the headerfield name in the first textbox and the search text in the second one.
Body - search in the actual text of the message.
Date - Filter message according to the date which they were sent: First, choose the conditions you want a message to meet - before a given time, or after it. Then choose the date.
Flag - First choose a flag, which can be Seen, Expunged, Flagged, etc. Choose a condition afterwards.
Priority - Choose between Highest, High, Normal, Low, Lowest
Size - Filter messages based on the size of the message in Kb (Kilobytes).
Color - Filter messages based on color flag
Account - Account-based filtering
Sender is in Addressbook - check if message sender is in addressbook
Match All - Match all messages automatically. Can be used to execute actions on every message of a folder repetitive.
Move Message - Move message to specified destination folder
Copy Message - Copy message to specified destination folder
Mark as Read - Mark message as Read/Flagged/Expunged
Delete Message - Delete message
Color Message - Assign color to message
Score Message - Spam filter analyzes the message, generates a scoring value and marks the message as either spam or non spam

section.title: Using Virtual Folders
section.para: If filters are not flexible enough for you, consider the use of vFolders (virtual folders). If you find yourself performing the same search again and again then read on.

Explaining what a vFolder does is not easy at all. It looks like a folder, it acts like a search, and you set it up like a filter. In other words, while a traditional folder actually contains messages, a vFolder is a view of messages that may be in several different folders. The messages it contains are determined on the fly, when the user selects a vFolder, using a set of filter criteria you specified before.
It is important to note that when you delete a message in a vFolder, Columba will automatically remove the message from the message list and from the folder it actually exists in.

Imagine a university with overlapping and changing groups of faculty, staff, administrators and students. In this situation vFolders often make for a better organization because they can accept overlapping groups in a way that regular folders and file systems cannot.

chapter.title: Configuring Columba
chapter.para: This chapter describes in detail all available configuration options of Columba, being it account configuration, mail options or general Columba-wide settings like fonts or proxy settings.

section.title: Configuring Accounts
section.para: Select Edit->Mail Account Settings... to open the account preferences dialog.
Selection Add opens the account wizard which will help you creating a new account.
Lets you edit the account options.
Deletes the currently selected account.

section.title: Identity Page
section.para: Choose a name for this new account. When using multiple accounts this will help you distinguishing them from each other.
You can declare one account to be your default account. When using multiple accounts, the default account will have higher priority in any tasks.
This is the real name assigned to this account, generally your first and last name. The text you enter here, is visible in the From: headerfield of all your outgoing messages.
Specify your email address here.
Your organisation will be visible in the X-Organisation: headerfield of all your outgoing messages. Most private individuals do not use this and leave it blank.
This is the return email address used in outgoing messages and recipients replies, if this address is different from your email address specified above.
If checked this lets you choose a textfile, which is always appended to all composed messages. Its the perfect place to easily attach an electronic version of your business cards.

section.title: Incoming Server Page
section.para: This is the name you use to login to this email account. For example, in the upcoming mail account donald@mail.com, the login name is donald. This is a very common scheme used by most providers. Check with your Internet Service Provider if you are not sure what your login name is.
Name of your incoming mail server.
This is the port number Columba uses to connect to your mail server. Usually you do not need to change this option.

Depending on your mail server type, you have the choice between more or less secure authentication mechanisms. Most mail servers should work out-of-box with the default setup. But sometimes you need to manually choose a login method in order to make it work.

Use SSL (Secure Socket Layer) for server authentication and mail transfer security by having Columba automatically invoke the STARTTLS command method to start SSL. If your server does not support SSL, mail transfer will occur successfully, but will not be secured with SSL.

If you select this options, your password is remembered even if you quit and restart Columba so you should never be prompted to enter it again. If this option is turned off, you must enter your password each time connecting with your mail server. Select this option only if your PC is in a secure place.

section.title: Receiving Options Page
section.para: Enables interval message checking, meaning Columba automatically checks if new messages are available in background.
If Columba found new messages, should it download them automatically for you?

para.emphasis: Play sound when new messages arrive:

section.para: Play a sound when a new message arrives.

para.emphasis: Check for new messages every xxx minutes:

section.para: Specify the interval Columba should try to check for new messages. Some mail servers only allow mail-checking every 10 minutes or even longer delays. You should set this value to at least this minimum value.

If you select this options, Columba copies the message to your PC and leaves them on the mail server. If this is turned off, Columba transfers incoming messages to your PC and deletes them from your POP3 server. Most servers allow you to indicate whether to leave the messages on the server so you can retrieve it from several different computers at various times.

para.emphasis: Remove messages from server after xxx days (POP3 only):

section.para: Columba automatically deletes all messages older than xxx days from your POP3 server.
Selecting this option excludes your account from the mail check which is generally executed for all accounts when using the Receive and Send Messages action.
If you select this option, messages over the specified size are not downloaded. This can be useful on slow connections.

para.emphasis: Automatically apply Filters on Inbox (IMAP only):

section.para: If you select this option, filters of your IMAP folder are applied automatically when selecting the folder.

section.title: Outgoing Server Page
section.para: This is the name you use to login to this email account. For example, in the upcoming mail account donald@mail.com, the login name is donald. This is a very common scheme used by most providers. Check with your Internet Service Provider if you are not sure what your login name is.
Name of your outgoing mail server.
This is the port number Columba uses to connect to your mail server. Usually you do not need to change this option.

You have the choice between more or less secure authentication mechanisms. Most mail servers should work out-of-the-box with the default setup. But sometimes you need to manually choose a login method in order to make it work. Use the Check Supported Types button to receive a list of all available types from your server.

Use SSL (Secure Socket Layer) for server authentication and mail transfer security by having Columba automatically invoke the STARTTLS command method to start SSL. If your server does not support SSL, mail transfer will occur successfully, but will not be secured with SSL.

If you select this options, your password is remembered even if you quit and restart Columba so you should never be prompted to enter it again. If this option is turned off, you must enter your password each time connecting with your mail server. Select this option only if your PC is in a secure place.

section.title: Security Page
section.para: This lets you choose whether you want to use strong encryption with the OpenPGP-compatible open-source software GnuPG.

You need to specify at least your PGP user-id, generally your email address is sufficient.
You can choose one account to be the default account in the Identity Tab or in the Account Preferences dialog. Other accounts can use the setup of the default account for themselves. So, its easy to specify another account which uses the same POP3 mailserver, but not another SMTP server. You just need to select the use default account preferences checkbox to make it work.

section.title: Mail Options Dialog
section.para: If this option is selected, Columba shows the HTML part of a message, if it has been sent in both formats. This is called multipart/alternative messages. Basically messages which are send in two different formats at once, plain text or html. If unchecked, the plain text version is displayed. Note that many people will not open HTML messages as it is a favourite tool of spammers / virus writers. It is also often used with embedded graphics / hidden links to track when you actually displayed the message. While HTML can make a message more "pretty", it adds (sometimes greatly) to the size of the message and is considered by most security savvy users to be too great a security risk.

tip.para: The attachment viewer lets you view the alternative format.

section.para: HTML message text will transformed to plain text automatically before viewing.
Selecting this options makes the message viewer replace ASCII art with graphics.
If selected, the message viewer will show all attachments inline automatically. This is especially useful when reading messages containing lots of images attached.

Replaces the Java HTML viewer with your System's default web browser. This is in most cases either Internet Explorer or Firefox. In version 1.0 we had to disable support for this feature due to technical reasons.

para.emphasis: Mark messages as read after ~ seconds:

section.para: If this option is selected, Columba automatically marks a message as read after it was viewed by you. Specifying a interval of 0 seconds, immediately marks the message read.

para.emphasis: Ask when sending messages with empty subject:

section.para: When composing messages with an empty Subject: headerfield, you will be asked to enter a subject. If this option is not selected, Columba just sends the message with an empty subject. Be aware though that messages with blank subject fields are often deleted as spam by some people / filters (and even when the email address of the sender is known).

para.emphasis: Send HTML messages with alternative text part:

section.para: If this option is selected, HTML messages will be send in text plain and in HTML format. Sometimes people can not read HTML messages, so sending the text plain format additionally eliminates this problem.
Forward message as attachment, just adds the message as attachment. Whereas forwarding messages as quoted, lets you edit the quoted message bodytext.

tip.para: You can always explicitly forward a message in the format you like from the Message menu.

section.title: General Options Dialog
section.para: Lets you select a different language translation package. You can download many translation packages from our website. Just download the package of choice and save it to Columba's program folder or your configuration folder. Columba will automatically recognize the new package on restart.

This option lets you change the style of all the toolbars in Columba. You can enable icons, show icons with text and choose the location of the text. Turning off the display of toolbar icons will maximize the space available for displaying messages.

You can change the way Columba looks and feels with Themes (often also known as skins). New themes can be downloaded from our website. Just download the plugin and use the Plugin Manager to install the new Look and Feel. Restart of Columba is required.

para.emphasis: Overwrite Look and Feel font settings:

section.para: Look and Feels also choose individual fonts. This option allows you to change the font settings of Columba, independent from the used theme.
This is the font of all the controls like menus and buttons.
Font used by the message viewer and the composer. Usually this should be a fixed width font to allow easier editing of contents.

chapter.title: Extending Columba
chapter.para: A strength of Columba is its ability to easily integrate external tools or plugins.

section.title: Plugin Manager
section.para: The plugin manager lets you organize external plugins. Plugin Manager

Selecting this button will prompt you for a plugin located on your PC. This will automatically install the plugin for you. Note that for some plugins to work correctly, it may be necessary to restart Columba.
Deletes the selected plugin.
Shows detailed information about the selected plugin. This should be the first source of information for you.

section.title: External Tools Manager
section.para: External Tools are usually commandline tools, which are used by Columba or plugins to offer you certain functionality.
Press the Next button to go on.
If you do not have this tool installed, visit the URL shown below the description and download the tool. Press the Next button to go on.
Most of the time, the configuration wizard will automatically be able to find the tool on your PC. If not, you can use the Change button to do it manually.
